title: Delta Ursae Majoris
text:
Delta Ursae Majoris (δ Ursae Majoris, abbreviated Delta UMa, δ UMa), formally named Megrez , is a <a href="star">star</a> in the northern <a href="circumpolar%20constellation">circumpolar constellation</a> of <a href="Ursa%20Major">Ursa Major</a>. With an <a href="apparent%20magnitude">apparent magnitude</a> of +3.3, it is the dimmest of the seven stars in the <a href="Big%20Dipper">Big Dipper</a> <a href="asterism%20%28astronomy%29">asterism</a>. <a href="Parallax">Parallax</a> measurements yield a distance estimate of from the <a href="Sun">Sun</a>.
Stellar properties.
Delta Ursae Majoris has 63% more mass than the Sun and is about 1.4 times its radius. It has a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> of A3 V, which means it is an <a href="A-type%20main%20sequence%20star">A-type main sequence star</a> that is generating energy at its core through the <a href="nuclear%20fusion">nuclear fusion</a> of hydrogen. It shines at 14 times the luminosity of the Sun, with this energy being emitted from its outer envelope at an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of 9,480 K. This gives it the white hue typical of an A-type star.
This star has an <a href="infrared%20excess">excess emission of infrared radiation</a>, indicating the presence of circumstellar matter. This forms a <a href="debris%20disk">debris disk</a> around an orbital radius of 16 <a href="Astronomical%20Unit">Astronomical Unit</a>s from the star. This radius is unusually small for the estimated age of the disk, which may be explained by drag from the <a href="Poynting%E2%80%93Robertson%20effect">Poynting–Robertson effect</a> causing the dust to spiral inward.
It has two faint companions, a 10th magnitude star and an 11th magnitude star, both at an <a href="angular%20separation">angular separation</a> of two <a href="arcminute">arcminute</a>s from the primary.
Delta Ursae Majoris is a member of the <a href="Ursa%20Major%20moving%20group">Ursa Major moving group</a>, an <a href="stellar%20association">association</a> of stars that share a common motion through space and likely formed in the same <a href="molecular%20cloud">molecular cloud</a>. The <a href="Space%20velocity%20%28astronomy%29">space velocity</a> components of Delta Ursae Majoris in the <a href="galactic%20coordinate%20system">galactic coordinate system</a> are [U, V, W] = [+15.35, +1.17, –11.52].
Nomenclature.
"δ Ursae Majoris" (<a href="Latinisation%20of%20names">Latinised</a> to "Delta Ursae Majoris") is the star's <a href="Bayer%20designation">Bayer designation</a>.
It bore the traditional name "Megrez" and the historical name "Kaffa". "Megrez" comes from the "al-maghriz" 'the base [of the bear's tail]'. Professor Paul Kunitzch has been unable to find any clues as to the origin of the name "Kaffa", which appeared in a 1951 publication, "Atlas Coeli" (<a href="Skalnate%20Pleso%20Atlas%20of%20the%20Heavens">Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens</a>) by Czech astronomer <a href="Anton%C3%ADn%20Be%C4%8Dv%C3%A1%C5%99">Antonín Bečvář</a>.
The <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a>s knew this star as "<a href="Atri">Atri</a>", one of the <a href="Saptarishi">Seven Rishis</a>.
In <a href="Chinese%20astronomy">Chinese</a>, (), meaning "<a href="Purple%20Forbidden%20enclosure">Northern Dipper</a>", refers to an <a href="Asterism%20%28astronomy%29">asterism</a> equivalent to the Big Dipper. Consequently, the <a href="Chinese%20star%20names">Chinese name</a> for Delta Ursae Majoris itself is (, ) and (, ).
Namesakes.
<a href="USS%20Megrez%20%28AK-126%29">USS "Megrez" (AK-126)</a> was a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="Crater%20class%20cargo%20ship">Crater class cargo ship</a> named after the star.
